questions.text: A young female patient with a recent travel history comes to the OPD with a history of prolonged abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern. On examination, faint, salmon-colored macules are seen on the trunk. A serological test is used to confirm the diagnosis. This test is an example of
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of enteric fever/ typhoid fever. Widal test is an agglutination test done in case of typhoid fever.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. The clinical course may vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to a rapidly fatal disease. Clinical manifestations include malaise, step ladder pyrexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and myalgia. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen that fade on pressure. They appear in the second week and are seen as shown below

Widal test:

It is a type of tube agglutination test in which, H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli are measured in the serum sample. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.

Interpretation of Widal test: 

  • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
  • H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 is considered significant.

Other options

  • Option b: In tube flocculation test, serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to tubes containing a fixed quantity of antitoxin. The amount of toxin or toxoid that flocculates optimally with one unit of the antitoxin is defined as Lf dose. Example: Kahn test for syphilis.
  • Option c: In slide flocculation test, a drop each of the antigen and antiserum are placed on the slide and mixed by shaking; appearance of floccules is taken as positive. Eg. VDRL test for syphilis
  • Option d: In Ring precipitation test, antigen solution is layered over a column of antiserum in a narrow tube. the precipitate is formed at the junction of the 2 liquids. Example: Ascoli’s thermoprecipitin test for detection of anthrax antigen.

Tube flocculation, slide flocculation and ring precipitation test are all types of precipitation tests.

questions.text: A patient presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. The culture of the specimen shows the appearance given in the image, at 37°C. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image above showing thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance, in the culture at 37°C is suggestive of Blastomycosis dermatitidis. It causes North American blastomycosis.

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  • Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions or abscess formation. 
  • Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.
  • Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other Options:

Option A: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes Brazilian/South American blastomycosis.

Option C: Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis/Darling's disease.

Option D: Coccidioides immitis causes valley fever.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 75 year old man, who was on a tapering dose of methylprednisolone presented with complaints of non productive cough and chest pain. A chest CT scan revealed heterogeneous consolidation in the left upper lobe with cavitation. A biopsy showed the presence of a fungus, as seen in the image below. Voriconazole was started empirically for the infection. Identify the fungus based on its microscopic appearance:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fungal respiratory infection in a patient taking corticosteroids along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis caused by Aspergillus niger.

The microscopic appearance of Aspergillus niger is characterized by:

  • The vesicle is globular shaped
  • Phialides are in two rows
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black

Invasive disease may develop as an acute pneumonic process following the inhalation and germination of these conidia. Patients at risk for invasive aspergillosis are

  • lymphocytic or myelogenous leukemia and lymphoma
  • stem cell transplant recipients
  • individuals taking corticosteroids
  • AIDS patients with CD4 cell counts less than 50 CD4 cells/μL

Patients may present with fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Hyphae may invade the lumens and walls of blood vessels leading to thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Rapid administration of native or lipid formulation of amphotericin B or voriconazole is indicated in these cases.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • Vesicle is conical or flask shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from upper third of the vesicle, and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus Flavus 

  • Vesicle is globular shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in one or two rows.
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option D: Penicillium spp has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores. Chains of conidia are produced by 2 rows of sterigmata/phialides and give it a brush or broom appearance.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is crying uncontrollably and is complaining of ear pain. He has a high-grade fever, cold, and nose block. The otoscopic examination showed the following finding. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of severe ear pain, fever, and cold with the otoscopic image showing red and bulging tympanic membrane are likely to be acute suppurative otitis media. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of this condition. Other organisms that can cause these are:

  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Streptococcus pyogenes
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Clinical features: The child may present with a cold, fever, and earache. If the tympanic membrane ruptures, ear discharge might also be there.

In the stage of presuppuration, there might be a leash of blood vessels that appear along with the handle of the malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane giving it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the entire tympanic membrane becomes red.

Management:

Since the most common organism responsible are Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenza, antibiotics should be started. The effective drugs in acute otitis media are ampicillin (50 mg/kg/day in four divided doses) and amoxicillin (40 mg/kg/day in three divided doses).

Decongestant nasal drops- ephedrine, oxymetazoline, and xylometazoline nasal drops can be used to decrease the edema of the eustachian tube, and promote middle ear ventilation.

Oral nasal decongestants like pseudoephedrine in combination with an antihistamine are effective in treating nasal blockade.

Analgesics and antipyretics are used to relieve pain and fever

If there is ear discharge, it has to be mopped with sterile cotton buds. An antibiotic wick may also be inserted.

Myringotomy: It is incising the eardrum to evacuate pus and is indicated when the drum is bulging and there is acute pain, incomplete resolution despite antibiotics, persistent conductive hearing loss, and persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.

questions.text: A 44-year-old cave explorer presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Findings of microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage are shown below. Identify the organism and the stain used.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black stained cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. The chest x-ray is normal in case of mild symptoms and shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric in later stages. Pneumatocele and pneumothorax are characteristic chest radiographic findings. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) or pentamidine is the treatment. HIV patients with CD4 count <200/μL should be started on prophylaxis with TMP-SMX.

Histoplasma capsulatum spreads by inhalation of spores from bat or bird droppings. It causes flu-like illness, anorexia, dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. X-ray shows signs of pneumonitis with prominent hilar or mediastinal adenopathy and not pneumatocele. It is also stained with methenamine silver or Giemsa stain.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with fever and altered sensorium for two days, with the following rash on his trunk and legs. His BP is 70/50 mmHg and neck stiffness is present. Lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF with 4200 cells/μL, a protein level of 198 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following correctly describes the organisms causing this condition?

choices.text: Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidize glucose and maltose
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidase negative, catalase negative
Gram-negative diplococci, oxidize lactose and sucrose

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing petechial rashes are suggestive of fulminant meningococcemia. This condition is caused by Neisseria meningitidis/meningococci- gram-negative diplococci that oxidize glucose and maltose.

Neisseria meningitidis is an aerobic, gram-negative, nonmotile diplococcus. They are catalase and oxidase positive. Glucose and maltose are oxidized, but lactose and sucrose are not oxidized.

The cocci spread from the nasopharynx to the meninges by traveling along the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve with an initial flu-like infection.  Meningococcemia presents as an acute onset fever with chills, malaise with a petechial rash in early disease. The patient develops signs of meningitis, such as intense headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck. It may progress to a coma within a few hours.

Fulminant meningococcemia is more severe, presenting with a high fever and a hemorrhagic rash; the patient may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation and ultimate circulatory collapse with bilateral hemorrhagic necrosis of the adrenal glands with subsequent adrenal failure, also known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: During antibody screening for Hepatitis B infection, the following class of antibodies against HbcAg was detected in high titres in a patient. What is the most probable Hepatitis B infection status of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody. High titers of IgM antibodies signify a recent infection.

IgM antibody acts against the core antigen (IgM anti-Hbc) of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) and is predominant in acute infections. Later, it is replaced by IgG antibodies (IgG anti-Hbc).

Specific diagnosis of hepatitis B rests on the serological demonstration of the viral markers:

  • HBsAg is the first marker seen in the blood following infection and can be detected prior to the clinical manifestation and elevation of transaminases. Typically, they disappear within about two months of the start of clinical disease, but may sometimes persist for six months. Anti-HBs antibodies appear when the antigens are no longer detectable and they remain for very long periods. Anti-HBs are the protective antibody.
  • HBcAg cannot be demonstrated in circulation since it lies enclosed within the HBsAg coat, but its antibody, anti-HBc is the earliest marker seen in blood a week or two after the appearance of HBsAg. It remains for a lifetime and thus indicates a prior infection.
  • HBeAg appears in blood along with HBsAg or following its appearance. Circulating HBeAg is an indicator of active intrahepatic viral replication, and the presence of DNA polymerase, HBV DNA, and virions, reflect high infectivity.

Other options:

Option B: Remote HBV infection is characterized by the presence of IgG anti-Hbc antibodies.

Option C: People vaccinated against Hep B will have antibodies only against surface antigen HbsAg, and not against the core antigen. 

Option D: Hepatitis B carriers have IgG and HBsAg seen.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of brittle hair and hair loss. Hair under microscopy is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complaints of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.
  • White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white, or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, and facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

Other options:

Option B: Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum, especially affecting the palms. It produces brownish/blackish macular lesions. It is caused by Exophiala werneckii. 

Option C: Pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or Tricholipodystrophy or Steely hair disease which is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Option D: Trichorrhexis nodosa is associated with node formation and fractures. The classic appearance, shown in the image below, is known as thrust paintbrush appearance as if two paintbrushes are rubbing against each other. It is associated with trauma to the hair shaft and arginosuccinic aciduria.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. The culture on MacConkey agar showed the appearance of non-lactose fermenting colonies. Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction is positive. What is the most likely organism implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicating, non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar, and a positive Phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) Reaction in a patient with lower urinary tract symptoms is suggestive of Proteus infection.

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus. All members of the tribe Protea have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus can cause urinary tract infections. Struvite stones (triple phosphate stones) are usually seen in a setting of infection with urease-producing bacteria like Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

Image showing a positive PPA reaction:

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as,

Lactose fermenters Escherichia, Klebsiella, Enterobacter 
Late lactose fermenters Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia
Non-lactose fermenters Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

  • Providencia - late fermenter

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaints of a painless ulcer on his penis. The complement fixation test is found to be positive. All of the following immunoglobulins are involved in this reaction, except:
questions.solution:
All the given immunoglobulins are involved in complement fixation except IgG4.

A painless ulcer over the penis with a positive complement fixation test is suggestive of the diagnosis of syphilis.

Complement cannot bind to the free antigen or antibodies directly. It can bind to those antibodies that have combined with their antigen. The ability of these antigen-antibody complexes to bind or fix complement is utilized in the complement fixation test. The test is performed in two steps and involves five reagents: antigen, antibody, complement, sheep erythrocytes, and an amboceptor (rabbit antibody to sheep RBCs). 

Compliment fixation involves the immunoglobulins IgM, IgG3, IgG1, and IgG2 (in this order).

questions.text: A diabetic patient is admitted with symptoms of ear pain and ear discharge.  A swab was taken and cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe, catalase positive, and shows the following motility. Which of the following is responsible for its pathogenicity?

choices.text: Exotoxin A and a slime layer

questions.solution:
The given clinical features, laboratory findings and the video shows swarming motility of the bacterial growth on a solid agar plate are suggestive of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer are responsible for its pathogenicity. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown). It shows a positive oxidase reaction and is non-lactose fermenting in nature.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Other options-

Option A: Shiga toxin acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Shigella dysenteriae causes acute onset of symptoms(fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus which acts via preformed Type A enterotoxin. Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food.

Option D: The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with multiple superficial nodular lesions. A picture of his lesions is shown below. The lepromin test is negative and he is diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy. Which of the following is not consistent with his form of disease?

choices.text: Due to deficient cell mediated immunity
Lesions contain predominantly CD4+ T cells
Lesions contain predominantly CD8+ T cells
Not more susceptible to viral opportunistic infections

questions.solution:
The statement 'lesions contain predominantly CD4+ T cells' is not consistent with lepromatous leprosy. It is associated with CD8+ T cells.

The given image depicts a male patient with cutaneous nodules over the face and loss of eyebrows, consistent with nodular lepromatous leprosy. 

Mycobacterium leprae is a gram-positive, acid-fast bacillus that causes leprosy. Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease that affects the skin and peripheral nerves. 

There are different forms of leprosy depending on the immune status of the person who is infected. 

The lepromatous form occurs when there is poor cell-mediated immunity (Option A). It is termed as 'multibacillary disease' as there are numerous bacilli seen within the lesions. The lepromata (superficial nodular granulomatous lesions) that develop contain vacuolated cells in different stages of development. The bacteria are also shed in nasal and oral secretions. The lepromatous form is considered to be very infectious. 

Within the lepromatous granulomas, there is an infiltrate of CD8+ T cells (Option C). In the tuberculous type, there are predominantly CD4+ T cells. 

In lepromatous leprosy, there is a deficiency in cell-mediated immunity. However, the deficiency is specifically for the lepra antigens. Individuals with this form are not more susceptible to other viral or parasitic infections (Option D) even though cell-mediated immunity is required. 

In tuberculoid leprosy, individuals have good resistance. There are not many lesions and if present, they are sharply demarcated. The lesions do not have extensive bacilli presence and it is not very infective. This form is termed 'paucibacillary disease'.

Other forms of leprosy also exist such as borderline, borderline tuberculous, borderline lepromatous types based on the Ridley-Jopling classification. These contain features of both tuberculous and lepromatous types. 

The lepromin test is one way to understand the immunity in a patient with leprosy. Lepromin antigens from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli are used and injected into the skin. It has two reactions: the early reaction (Fernandez) and the late reaction (Mitsuda). The early reaction develops within 1-2 days and will persist for 3-5 days. It is characterized by erythema and induration. The late reaction starts 1-2 weeks later with a peak at 4 weeks and then subsides. Here, there is an indurated nodule that may ulcerate.

The presence of a Mitsuda reaction is a measure of the cell-mediated immunity. It is not used to diagnose. It is used to classify, assess prognosis, resistance, and verify the identity of candidate lepra bacilli. The test is positive in tuberculoid leprosy and negative in lepromatous leprosy as seen in our patient. A positive reaction demonstrated good prognosis and resistance. 

The below image shows a histopathological slide of lepromatous leprosy. Here, large groups of lipid-laden macrophages filled with globi of pink/red acid-fast bacilli are seen.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with swelling in the lips, and face for the last 2 days. She gives a history of multiple similar episodes in the past and also says some of her relatives have similar complaints. On examination, non-pruritic subcutaneous edema is noted. This condition is associated with the deficiency of which of the following complements?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is associated with a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor. 

Hereditary angioneurotic edema (HAE) is an autosomal dominant condition due to low levels of plasma protein C1 inhibitor. Deficiencies of C1 inhibitors facilitate the unchecked activation of the classic complement pathway and biochemical systems including bradykinin systems. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator that caused neutrophil chemotaxis, capillary dilatation with plasma leakage, and smooth muscle relaxation.

Hereditary angioneurotic edema is characterized by episodic angioedema of the subcutaneous tissue like the face, hands, arms, genitals, or of the mucosa of the respiratory or alimentary tracts. They can present with non-pruritic subcutaneous tissue edema, paroxysmal colicky pain, or laryngeal edema.

Drugs like ecallantide, icatibant, C1-inhibitor derived from human plasma, or recombinant C1- inhibitor are used for acute attacks. Recombinant C1-inhibitor can be used for attacks and prophylaxis. Avoidance of triggers, estrogens, and ACE-inhibitors are included in the management plan.

questions.text: A stool sample of a person suffering from rice-water diarrhea is stained and observed under the microscope, which shows the following image. Which of the following is a selective medium for the growth of the organism shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of watery stools and the image showing the characteristic fish-in-stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae for which Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile-Sucrose agar is the selective medium.

Selective media contain an inhibiting substance that is added to a solid medium. This inhibits the growth of commensals and favors the growth of the required bacterium. 

Vibrio cholerae is aerobic, with scanty slow growth anaerobically. Growth is better in an alkaline medium. NaCl in 0.5–1% concentration is required for optimum growth.

Vibrio colonies can be identified by the string test. A loopful of the growth is mixed with sodium deoxycholate in saline on a slide. If the test is positive, the suspension loses its turbidity and forms a string when the loop is slowly pulled away from the suspension.

V. cholerae causes a diarrheal disease called cholera. It presents as profuse, painless, watery diarrhea, and vomiting. The pathogenesis involves the production of the cholera toxin which attaches to GM-1 ganglioside receptors on the jejunal epithelium cells.

Option A: Thayer-Martin medium selectively favours the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with vancomycin, gram-negative organisms with colistin, and fungi with nystatin.

The following image shows the Thayer-Martin medium.

Option C: Lowenstein-Jensen medium is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein-Jenson medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

The following image shows the Lowenstein-Jenson medium.

Option D: Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium is the transport medium for Vibrio species prepared with crude sea salt and peptone in one liter of distilled water and pH in the range of 8.6 - 8.8. In this medium, vibrios do not multiply but are viable for several weeks.

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer presented with a 6-month history of soft tissue swelling on the right jaw. On examination, a discharging sinus was found as seen below. On microscopic examination of the pus, sulfur granules appearance was seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A farmer with a lumpy jaw & discharging sinuses, with the pus having a sulfur granule appearance is characteristic of cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis typically presents as a painless nodule that indurates, with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. It is an indolent, slowly progressive, suppurative, and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions, with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules.

It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive device.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue, and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures (Sunray appearance).
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of Actinomyces colonies.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

 

The given image shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis:

Treatment:

  • Penicillin G is the drug of choice.
  • Duration of therapy: 6-12 months.
  • Other drugs that can be used: Amoxicillin, Erythromycin, Tetracycline, Doxycycline, Clindamycin, Minocycline.

Other options:

Option B: Chromoblastomycosis is commonly seen in tropical areas among agricultural workers and woodcutters who walk barefooted. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection. Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genera Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents. Diagnosis is by demonstration of sclerotic bodies (copper-penny bodies) in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae.

Option C: Bacillus anthracis infection manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows Gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce non-hemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Sporotrichosis caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, is commonly seen in gardeners following minor trauma. Patients present with skin nodules or lymph node ulceration. Microscopy shows asteroid bodies. It can be seen as an oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The smear prepared from the discharge was stained with Wayson stain and the finding is given below. Which bioterrorism category does the causative organism belong to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing a characteristic safety pin appearance on Wayson stain is suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. It belongs to category A bioterrorism.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis). Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

  1. Bubonic plague - This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. 
  2. Pneumonic plague - Occurs as a complication of septic plague or bubonic plague and bacilli can be isolated from sputum as well.
  3. Septic plague - It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with recurrent bouts of vomiting and abdominal cramps over the past three hours. He gives a history of consumption of fried rice at a restaurant 5 hours back. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette showing food poisoning within 2 hours of consumption of fried rice/ Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (serotypes 1, 3, 5) food poisoning.

Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus: one involves the stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other is independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with B. cereus is of two types:

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8–16 hours 1–5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

B. cereus produces lecithinase and ferments glucose but not mannitol. The presence of 1,00,000 or more bacteria per gram of stool is diagnostic. Anything less than that may be present as normal flora in the gut. Both types of illnesses are mild and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Food poisoning by Clostridium perfringens is usually caused by the consumption of cold or warmed-up meat dishes. After an incubation period of 8-24 hours, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting set in. Isolating heat-resistant C. perfringens type A from feces and food is used for the diagnosis.

Option B: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours. Demonstration of the enterotoxins is helpful to establish the diagnosis. It causes traveler's diarrhea in people from non-endemic areas visiting endemic areas.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning. It presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after 2–6 hours of consuming contaminated food. Meat, fish, milk, and milk products that are cooked and left at room temperature after contamination with Staphylococci, for a long enough time for the toxin to accumulate, are usually responsible. The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, and headache for the past 5 days. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the life cycle shown in the image is suggestive of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by leptospira. Humans are infected when the leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or through the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease).

Diagnosis includes:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposit of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.
  • Serotype-specific tests: 
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever.

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: Match the following images of genital tract infections to their microscopic images.
questions.solution:
Image (i) is of a strawberry cervix, which matches image C for Trichomas vaginalis. Trichomonas vaginalis can be identified by the presence of racquet shaped protozoan with four anterior flagella and one posterior flagellum. 

 

Image (ii) is of white curdy discharge in the vagina, which matches image A for Candida albicans. On a KOH wet mount, hyphae and spores of candida are seen. On culture, they appear as discrete creamy rounded budding yeast with a specific yeast-like odor.  

 

Image (iii) is of a homogenous white discharge, which matches image B for Bacterial vaginosis usually associated with Gardanella vaginalis. It can be identified by the presence of motile pear-shaped flagellate organisms. 

One can also appreciate the presence of clue cells- epithelial cells having a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria.

The image below shows the findings in bacterial vaginosis and the clue cells in the stained and wet mount preparation respectively.

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic presented to the casualty with fever, productive cough and dyspnea. Chest X-Ray was performed which showed the following finding. Sputum culture was sent which showed lactose fermenting, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing bulging fissure sign are highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumonia.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Classic chest X-ray findings include:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows bulging fissure sign. 

 

Klebsiella pneumoniae ferment lactose and forms mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. It ferments carbohydrates to produce acid and gas. 

The image below shows a comparison between colonies of E.coli on the left and K. pneumoniae on the right on MacConkey agar.

 

Other infections produced by K. pneumoniae include:

  • Neonatal sepsis
  • Catheter-associated urinary tract infection
  • Pyogenic abscesses
  • Meningitis
